> > The other interesting thing we've been doing lately with
> > this method entry
> > data is to walk the stack frames on method entry
> > notification to find the
> > calling methods, and then build an object interaction
> > diagram from that.
> > Besides displaying the interactions (useful for
> > debugging) we're also using
> > them to generate more tests for lower level collaborating objects.
>
> Can you tell us the round-about way you did this? Is there some
> API to call
> to get the stack trace?
>

When you get a method entry event notification in JPDA, the a model for the
calling thread, and associated stack are available, anchored in the method
entry event object. Just traverse the stack frames and extract the method
names to find the source and target of the interaction. These are all JPDA
classes.

So while I'm rambling on I feel the need to mention that one of the things
we did is provide a mechanism to apply discrete stimuli to the object under
test within a test case. One of the side effects of this is that we can
display interactions that resulted from an individual stimulus separately to
get a clear idea of the interactions that resulted from that particular
stimulus. So if a test case calls five methods on an object under test you
would see the interactions divided into five sections (likewise for the code
coverage metrics). This is one of the benefits of tight integration between
the test tool and the profiling mechanism.
